title: 107_s1351
content: The Act may be cited as the "Fugitive Apprehension Act of 2001". Administrative subpoenas can be used to apprehend fugitives. The "Fugitive Apprehension Act of 2001" amends Chapter 49 of title 18, United States Code by adding a section on administrative subpoenas to apprehend fugitives. A fugitive is defined as a person who flees or evades the jurisdiction of the court after being accused or convicted of a felony under Federal or State law. The term 'investigation' refers to the process of pursuing a State fugitive who has fled or evaded the jurisdiction of the court after being accused or convicted of a felony under Federal or State law. The Attorney General may subpoena witnesses in investigations related to apprehending fugitives who have fled jurisdiction, involving interstate or foreign commerce, or at the request of a State law enforcement official. The Attorney General may subpoena witnesses and records relevant to locating fugitives, with a reasonable return date for production. Witnesses can be required to appear within 500 miles of where they were served with a subpoena. The Attorney General can subpoena witnesses and records to locate fugitives. Witnesses summoned will be paid fees and mileage. Subpoenas can be served by designated agents or through personal delivery or certified mail for natural persons, and by delivering to officers or agents for corporations or associations. The Attorney General can subpoena witnesses and records to locate fugitives. Witnesses summoned will be paid fees and mileage. Subpoenas can be served by designated agents or through personal delivery or certified mail for natural persons, and by delivering to officers or agents for corporations or associations. The affidavit of the person serving the subpoena is proof of service. In cases of refusal to obey a subpoena, the Attorney General can seek court intervention to compel compliance. Failure to obey the court order may result in contempt charges. The court may punish failure to obey its order as contempt. Process to enforce the order can be served in any judicial district. A recipient of a subpoena can petition to modify or quash it within 20 days. The Attorney General shall issue guidelines for administrative subpoenas, which must be approved by senior supervisory personnel and the US Attorney. Nondisclosure requirements are also outlined. The Attorney General may seek a court order to prevent disclosure of an administrative subpoena if it may endanger individuals, lead to flight from prosecution, evidence tampering, witness intimidation, or serious jeopardy. The Attorney General can seek a court order to prevent disclosure of records or items requested in a subpoena if it may seriously jeopardize an investigation or cause undue delay of a trial. Any person who produces the requested records in good faith is immune from civil liability for such production. Administrative subpoenas can be used to apprehend fugitives.
